Title: Myelo- and cytoarchitecture of the granular frontal cortex and surrounding regions in the strepsirhine primate Galago and the anthropoid primate Macaca
Abstract: "As the first part of a comparative investigation of primate frontal cortex, we compared the frontal architectonic organization of Galago, a small-brained, strepsirhine (or "prosimian") primate, to that of an anthropoid primate, Macaca, by using myelin- and Nissl-stained material. We were able to distinguish many more areas in both taxa than have been recognized in most previous studies of the primate frontal lobe. In particular, we were able to subdivide many of the areas shown in the commonly cited architectonic map of Walker (J. Comp. Neurol. 73:59-86, 1940). Delineation of areas was greatly facilitated by the use of the Gallyas technique for staining myelin. The areal organization of much of frontal cortex (specifically, the premotor, orbital, and medial regions) appears to be very similar in Galago and Macaca. In these regions, we were able to recognize the same complement of areas in both taxa, with few exceptions. In the granular frontal cortex (GFC), by contrast, we were able to distinguish about twice as many areas in Macaca as in Galago. For most of the GFC areas of Galago, there are architectonically similar areas in Macaca; the areas shared by both taxa correspond mainly to the arcuate and superior areas of Macaca (i.e., the region encompassed by Walker's areas 45, 8A, and 8B). However, there are many additional, more rostral, areas in Macaca for which there are no obvious homologues in Galago. In particular, Galago lacks cortex resembling the distinctive, lightly myelinated cortex of the Macaca principal sulcus (Walker's area 46 and its subdivisions). Our results are difficult to reconcile with the view that frontal lobe organization varies little across taxa. Rather, they suggest that granular frontal cortex underwent considerable change during primate evolution, including the addition of new areas in anthropoids."

@BrainMaps.Comments: The companion article, PG91b, shows the same map for the prefrontal cortex, combined with a parcellation for the rest of the cortex.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "...our study confirms many of Walker's lines of division, and his parcellation will be taken as the framework for the present account...we use myeloarchitecture to characterize additional subdivisions of Walker's areas." (p. 450)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The polar division of GFC [granular frontal cortex] consists of the cortex occupying both banks of the rostral principal sulcus...and Walker's area 10, which covers all aspects of the frontal pole (Figs. 4E, 5)." (p. 456)

"The ventral GFC [granular frontal cortex] region consists of a single area, Walker's area 11, which occupies the lateral aspect of the orbital surface at levels anterior to area 13 (Figs. 4, 5, 16C,E)." (p. 456)

"Brodmann (1909) divided the 'Regio praecentralis' of anthropoid and strepsirhine primates into two areas, 4 and 6, and this basic division is still widely employed. Brodmann's area 4 corresponds at least approximately to the physiologically defined primary motor area (M1)..." (p. 441)

"We use these variations to distinguish primary motor cortex from premotor cortex and to divide the latter into three main divisions: a dorsal division...and a ventral division...and the opercular areas (PrCO and OFO) of Roberts and Akert (1963)." (p. 441)

"We use these variations to distinguish primary motor cortex from premotor cortex and to divide the latter into three main divisions: a dorsal division...and a ventral division...and the opercular areas (PrCO and OFO) of Roberts and Akert (1963)." (p. 441)

"Dorsally, within the cingulate sulcus (CgS), there is an elongaetd territory of paralimbic cortex (Para), which is intermediate in architecture between the lightly myelinated cortex of area 24 and the heavily myelinated, large-cell tissue of the overlying precentral region (Sanides, 1970..."
"Area 24 occupies the anterior cingulate gyrus (Brodmann, 1909; Walker, 1940). (This area can be further subdivided along dorsoventral lines, as demonstrated by Vogt et al., 1987.)"
"Area 24 occupies the anterior cingulate gyrus (Brodmann, 1909; Walker, 1940). (This area can be further subdivided along dorsoventral lines, as demonstrated by Vogt et al., 1987.)"
"Area 24 occupies the anterior cingulate gyrus (Brodmann, 1909; Walker, 1940). (This area can be further subdivided along dorsoventral lines, as demonstrated by Vogt et al., 1987.)"
"...the cortex occupying both banks of rostral principal sulcus, which we denote as area 46r (a designation introduced by Barbas and Pandya, 1989)..." (pp. 456)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: BP89 recognize distinct rostral parts of their ventral and dorsal divisions of area 46 (see pp. 357, 360 of BP89).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: ""The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas...The lightly myelinated cortex of the PS is bordered ventrally by Walker's area 12...Differences in myelination make it possible to distinguish two divisions of area 12 (Figs. 16D, 21). One division, area 12vl, occupies much of the ventrolateral convexity and is characterized by numerous thick vertical fascicles. The second division, area 12orb, is located mostly on the orbital surface, although it extends for a short distance onto the convexity ventral to 12vl." (p. 453-456)

""The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas...The lightly myelinated cortex of the PS is bordered ventrally by Walker's area 12...Differences in myelination make it possible to distinguish two divisions of area 12 (Figs. 16D, 21). One division, area 12vl, occupies much of the ventrolateral convexity and is characterized by numerous thick vertical fascicles. The second division, area 12orb, is located mostly on the orbital surface, although it extends for a short distance onto the convexity ventral to 12vl." (p. 453-456)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...The cortex of area 13 can be subdivided into medial and lateral subdivisions, occupying the orbital sulcus (13M) and convexity lateral to the sulcus (13L), respectively." (p. 446)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...The cortex of area 13 can be subdivided into medial and lateral subdivisions, occupying the orbital sulcus (13M) and convexity lateral to the sulcus (13L), respectively." (p. 446)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...Area 14 occupies the gyrus rectus, medial to the OS (Figs. 4-7). It can be divided into several areas arrayed mediolaterally...At anterior levels, the cortex of the gyrus rectus undergoes a modest increase in the density amd distinctiveness of layer IV; we refer to this area as area 14A (Fig. 13)." (p. 446)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...Area 14 occupies the gyrus rectus, medial to the OS (Figs. 4-7). It can be divided into several areas arrayed mediolaterally...The lateral division, area 14L, occupies the convexity between the orbital and olfactory sulci." (p. 446)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...Area 14 occupies the gyrus rectus, medial to the OS (Figs. 4-7). It can be divided into several areas arrayed mediolaterally...on the most ventral part of the medial surface, vertical fibers are reduced; we term this zone 14M." (p. 446)
"Area 24 occupies the anterior cingulate gyrus (Brodmann, 1909; Walker, 1940)."
"Area 24 occupies the anterior cingulate gyrus (Brodmann, 1909; Walker, 1940)."

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...For example, the ventrolateral division of Walker's area 14 is designated as area 14VL." (p. 446)

"...our observations, particularly in myelin, indicate that the orbital region contains many architectonically distinct units. We have named most of these units as subdivisions of Walker's areas 13 and 14, using suffixes to indicate location...Area 14 occupies the gyrus rectus, medial to the OS (Figs. 4-7). It can be divided into several areas arrayed mediolaterally...Myelination increases again in the ventromedial area, 14VM, which covers the crown of the rectus gyrus." (p. 446)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas...As discussed in a previous paper (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989) principalis cortex can be divided into a series of anteroposteriorly elongated areas (Figs. 4, 5)...We described three myeloarchitectonic divisions: ...46d...46v...46vr...Here we also include a fourth area covering a narrow strip along the dorsal rim of the PS (46dr)." (pp. 453-455)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). (pp. 453-455)

"...the cortex occupying both banks of rostral principal sulcus, which we denote as area 46r..." (pp. 456)

"The superior division of GFC [granular frontal cortex] corresponds approximately to area 8B of Walker (Figs. 2, 5)..We distinguish two divisions of the superior region: area 8Bd, which lies on the shoulder, and area 8Bm, located on the medial wall at the same levels." (p. 453)

"The superior division of GFC [granular frontal cortex] corresponds approximately to area 8B of Walker (Figs. 2, 5)..We distinguish two divisions of the superior region: area 8Bd, which lies on the shoulder, and area 8Bm, located on the medial wall at the same levels." (p. 453)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas. Area 9 is divisible into dorsal (9d) and medial (9m) areas." (p. 453)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas. Area 9 is divisible into dorsal (9d) and medial (9m) areas." (p. 453)
"Narrow strips of thin, poorly laminated allocortex (the induseum griseum, IG) and periallocortex (area 33) lie in close apposition to the corpus callosum (Stephan and Andy, 1970)."
"Narrow strips of thin, poorly laminated allocortex (the induseum griseum, IG) and periallocortex (area 33) lie in close apposition to the corpus callosum (Stephan and Andy, 1970)."

"The arcuate GFC [granular frontal cortex] occupies the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus and neighboring convexity cortex...Walker recognized two divisions of this region, area 45, located along the ventrolateral limb of the arcuate sulcus, and area 8A, located dorsal to 45 in the arcuate concavity...We have modified this scheme, as shown in Fig. 5, dividing the arcuate region into four areas, three of which are largely buried within the anterior bank of AS (areas 45, 8Ac, and 8Am), and a fourth which lies on the convexity immediately rostral to the AS (area 8Ar)." (p. 453)

"The arcuate GFC [granular frontal cortex] occupies the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus and neighboring convexity cortex...Walker recognized two divisions of this region, area 45, located along the ventrolateral limb of the arcuate sulcus, and area 8A, located dorsal to 45 in the arcuate concavity...We have modified this scheme, as shown in Fig. 5, dividing the arcuate region into four areas, three of which are largely buried within the anterior bank of AS (areas 45, 8Ac, and 8Am), and a fourth which lies on the convexity immediately rostral to the AS (area 8Ar)." (p. 453)

"The arcuate GFC [granular frontal cortex] occupies the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus and neighboring convexity cortex...Walker recognized two divisions of this region, area 45, located along the ventrolateral limb of the arcuate sulcus, and area 8A, located dorsal to 45 in the arcuate concavity...We have modified this scheme, as shown in Fig. 5, dividing the arcuate region into four areas, three of which are largely buried within the anterior bank of AS (areas 45, 8Ac, and 8Am), and a fourth which lies on the convexity immediately rostral to the AS (area 8Ar)." (p. 453)

"The arcuate GFC [granular frontal cortex] occupies the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus and neighboring convexity cortex...Walker recognized two divisions of this region, area 45, located along the ventrolateral limb of the arcuate sulcus, and area 8A, located dorsal to 45 in the arcuate concavity...We have modified this scheme, as shown in Fig. 5, dividing the arcuate region into four areas, three of which are largely buried within the anterior bank of AS (areas 45, 8Ac, and 8Am), and a fourth which lies on the convexity immediately rostral to the AS (area 8Ar)." (p. 453)

"As discussed in a previous paper (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989) principalis cortex can be divided into a series of anteroposteriorly elongated areas (Figs. 4, 5)...We described three myeloarchitectonic divisions: ...46d...46v...46vr...Here we also include a fourth area covering a narrow strip along the dorsal rim of the PS (46dr). (This zone was treated as part of area 9 in Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989)." (pp. 453-455)

"Medial to area 6D, the medial wall of the hemisphere and dorsomedial shoulder is occupied by the medial premotor cortex (area 6M; referred to as M2 by Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 444)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: This statement is not entirely compatible with a comparison of the figures in the two articles: In the map of PG91a 6m directly borders medial area 4 or MI (p. 437, Fig. 5 in PG91a), whereas in the map of BP87 MII is separated from area 4 by the medial part of 6DC (p. 213 in BP87).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Our architectonic observations in Macaca indicate that area 6V can be divided into dorsal (6Va) and ventral (6Vb) zones (Figs. 4, 5) as previously reported by Barbas and Pandya (1987) and Vogt and Vogt (1919)..." (p. 444)

"Our architectonic observations in Macaca indicate that area 6V can be divided into dorsal (6Va) and ventral (6Vb) zones (Figs. 4, 5) as previously reported by Barbas and Pandya (1987) and Vogt and Vogt (1919)..." (p. 444)

"The location and architectonic characteristics of area 8Ac correspond closely to those of the low-threshold frontal eye field (FEF), based on the corelative microstimulation and architectonic studies of Bruce et al. (1985) and Stanton et al. (1989)."

"The superior division of GFC [granular frontal cortex] corresponds approximately to area 8B of Walker (Figs. 2, 5)..We distinguish two divisions of the superior region: area 8Bd, which lies on the shoulder, and area 8Bm, located on the medial wall at the same levels." (p. 453)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas. Area 9 is divisible into dorsal (9d) and medial (9m) areas." (p. 453)

"The areas of midfrontal GFC [granular frontal cortex] region replace the arcuate and superior GFC regions anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5). Walker (1940) recognized three divisions of this region (Fig. 2): area 9, covering the dorsolateral convexity and dorsomedial surface; area 46, lining the principal sulcus; and area 12, occupying the ventrolateral convexity and extending onto the orbital surface. We have subdivided each of Walker's areas. Area 9 is divisible into dorsal (9d) and medial (9m) areas." (p. 453)
"Narrow strips of thin, poorly laminated allocortex (the induseum griseum, IG) and periallocortex (area 33) lie in close apposition to the corpus callosum (Stephan and Andy, 1970)."
"Narrow strips of thin, poorly laminated allocortex (the induseum griseum, IG) and periallocortex (area 33) lie in close apposition to the corpus callosum (Stephan and Andy, 1970)."

"The arcuate GFC [granular frontal cortex] occupies the anterior bank of the arcuate sulcus and neighboring convexity cortex...Walker recognized two divisions of this region, area 45, located along the ventrolateral limb of the arcuate sulcus, and area 8A, located dorsal to 45 in the arcuate concavity...We have modified this scheme, as shown in Fig. 5, dividing the arcuate region into four areas, three of which are largely buried within the anterior bank of AS (areas 45, 8Ac, and 8Am), and a fourth which lies on the convexity immediately rostral to the AS (area 8Ar)." (p. 453)

(p. 453)

"As discussed in a previous paper (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989) principalis cortex can be divided into a series of anteroposteriorly elongated areas (Figs. 4, 5)...We described three myeloarchitectonic divisions: ...46d...46v...46vr...Here we also include a fourth area covering a narrow strip along the dorsal rim of the PS (46dr). (This zone was treated as part of area 9 in Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1989)." (pp. 453-455)

"Medial to area 6D, the medial wall of the hemisphere and dorsomedial shoulder is occupied by the medial premotor cortex (area 6M; referred to as M2 by Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 444)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: This statement is not entirely compatible with a comparison of the figures in the two articles: In the map of PG91a 6m directly borders medial area 4 or MI (p. 437, Fig. 5 in PG91a), whereas in the map of BP87 MII is separated from area 4 by the medial part of 6DC (p. 213 in BP87).

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Our architectonic observations in Macaca indicate that area 6V can be divided into dorsal (6Va) and ventral (6Vb) zones (Figs. 4, 5) as previously reported by Barbas and Pandya (1987) and Vogt and Vogt (1919)..." (p. 444)

"Our architectonic observations in Macaca indicate that area 6V can be divided into dorsal (6Va) and ventral (6Vb) zones (Figs. 4, 5) as previously reported by Barbas and Pandya (1987) and Vogt and Vogt (1919)..." (p. 444)

"The location and architectonic characteristics of area 8Ac correspond closely to those of the low-threshold frontal eye field (FEF), based on the corelative microstimulation and architectonic studies of Bruce et al. (1985) and Stanton et al. (1989)."

publication.title: Myelo- and cytoarchitecture of the granular frontal cortex and surrounding regions in the strepsirhine primate Galago and the anthropoid primate Macaca
publication.abstract: "As the first part of a comparative investigation of primate frontal cortex, we compared the frontal architectonic organization of Galago, a small-brained, strepsirhine (or "prosimian") primate, to that of an anthropoid primate, Macaca, by using myelin- and Nissl-stained material. We were able to distinguish many more areas in both taxa than have been recognized in most previous studies of the primate frontal lobe. In particular, we were able to subdivide many of the areas shown in the commonly cited architectonic map of Walker (J. Comp. Neurol. 73:59-86, 1940). Delineation of areas was greatly facilitated by the use of the Gallyas technique for staining myelin. The areal organization of much of frontal cortex (specifically, the premotor, orbital, and medial regions) appears to be very similar in Galago and Macaca. In these regions, we were able to recognize the same complement of areas in both taxa, with few exceptions. In the granular frontal cortex (GFC), by contrast, we were able to distinguish about twice as many areas in Macaca as in Galago. For most of the GFC areas of Galago, there are architectonically similar areas in Macaca; the areas shared by both taxa correspond mainly to the arcuate and superior areas of Macaca (i.e., the region encompassed by Walker's areas 45, 8A, and 8B). However, there are many additional, more rostral, areas in Macaca for which there are no obvious homologues in Galago. In particular, Galago lacks cortex resembling the distinctive, lightly myelinated cortex of the Macaca principal sulcus (Walker's area 46 and its subdivisions). Our results are difficult to reconcile with the view that frontal lobe organization varies little across taxa. Rather, they suggest that granular frontal cortex underwent considerable change during primate evolution, including the addition of new areas in anthropoids."
